Phyllis Amaral This critical review is focused on six contentious issues relevant to those programs in which older paraprofessionals work with their elderly peers: (a) the intense emphasis on preventive mental_health benefits for the helpers via the provision of imperative roles; (b) the demanding range of roles of older paraprofessionals, including peer counseling, casework and outreach, community organization and aggressive gerontological advocacy, and other challenging adjunctive roles in agencies; (c) the wide inconsistency in recruitment, selection, and training practices; (d) the compelling rationale of indigenousness or helper-age similarity as uniquely intensifying the effectiveness of older paraprofessionals; (e) the minimal integration of elderly paraprofessional programs into the resistant mental_health system; and (f) the alarming paucity of program outcome evaluations.
